metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Simultaneous observation dataset of land surface temperature in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin
metadata.description:
The aim of the simultaneous observation of land surface temperature is obtaining the land surface temperature of different kinds of underlying surface, including greenhouse film, the roof, road, ditch, concrete floor and so on, while the sensor of thermal infrared go into the experimental areas of artificial oases eco-hydrology on the middle stream. All the land surface temperature data will be used for validation of the retrieved land surface temperature from thermal infrared sensor and the analysis of the scale effect of the land surface temperature, and finally serve for the validation of the plausibility checks of the surface temperature product from remote sensing.
1. Observation time and other details
On 25 June, 2012, ditch and asphalt road surface temperatures were observed once every five minutes using handheld infrared thermometers recorded.
On 26 June, 2012, ditch and asphalt road surface temperatures were observed once every five minutes using handheld infrared thermometers while greenhouse film and concrete floor surface temperatures were observed once every one second using self-recording point thermometer.
On 29 June, 2012, concrete floor surface temperatures were observed continuously using handheld infrared thermometers during the sensor of TASI go into the region. At the same time, greenhouse film and concrete floor surface temperatures were observed once every one second using self-recording point thermometer.
On 30 June, 2012, asphalt road, ditch, bare soil, melonry and ridge of field surface temperatures were observed continuously using handheld infrared thermometers during the sensor of TASI go into the region. At the same time, greenhouse film and concrete floor surface temperatures were observed once every one second using self-recording point thermometer.
On 10 July, 2012, asphalt road, ditch, bare soil, melonry and ridge of field surface temperatures were observed once every one minute using handheld infrared thermometers during the sensor of TASI go into the region. At the same time, concrete floor surface temperatures were observed once every six second using self-recording point thermometer.
On 26 July, 2012, asphalt road, concrete floor, bare soil and melonry surface temperatures were observed once every one minute using handheld infrared thermometers during the sensor of WiDAS go into the region. At the same time, greenhouse film and concrete floor surface temperatures were observed once every six second using self-recording point thermometer.
On 2 August, 2012, corn field and concrete floor surface temperatures were observed using handheld infrared thermometers. At the same time, greenhouse film and concrete floor surface temperatures were observed once every six second using self-recording point thermometer. For corn field, twelve sites were selected according to the flight strip of the WiDAS sensor, and for each site one plot surface temperatures were recorded continuously during the sensor of WiDAS go into the region.
On 3 August, 2012, corn field and concrete floor surface temperatures were observed using handheld infrared thermometers. At the same time, greenhouse film and concrete floor surface temperatures were observed once every six second using self-recording point thermometer. For corn field, fourteen sites were selected according to the flight strip of the WiDAS sensor, and for each site three plots surface temperatures were recorded continuously during the sensor of WiDAS go into the region.
2. Instrument parameters and calibration
The field of view of the self-recording point thermometer and the handheld infrared thermometer are 10 and 1 degree, respectively. The emissivity of the latter was assumed to be 0.95. The observation heights of the self-recording point thermometer for the greenhouse film and the concrete floor were 0.5 m and 1 m, respectively. All instruments were calibrated three times (on 6 July, 5 August and 20 September, 2012) using black body during observation.
3. Data storage
All the observation data were stored in excel.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to acquire multiscale eco-hydrological observations in a heterogeneous surface environment?
Example.Answer: The HiWATER experiment utilized instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions, and a superstation within the oasis. This method enabled the capture of multiscale eco-hydrological processes through a combination of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing missions.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting and utilizing multiscale environmental data for eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge in collecting multiscale environmental data is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes. HiWATER aimed to address this challenge by conducting intensive observation periods and continuous observations with a comprehensive setup of various instruments.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that combines ground measurements and remote sensing data in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: A dataset obtained from the HiWATER experiment combines synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes with hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data, including LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer, to provide a multiscale dataset for eco-hydrological research.

Feature Specification.Answer: poor availability of multiscale observations, intensive observation periods, continuous hydrometeorological observations, hierarchically nested scales

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'synchronical ground measurements' in the context of eco-hydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Synchronical ground measurements refer to the simultaneous collection of data on vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes at the ground level, which is conducted in conjunction with other remote sensing and instrument-based observations to provide a comprehensive multi-scale dataset in the field of eco-hydrology.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using handheld infrared thermometers compare to those using fixed automatic temperature loggers in terms of frequency and application?
Comparison.Answer: The handheld infrared thermometers were used with varying observation frequencies, such as every 5 minutes or continuously when sensors were overhead, and were applied to various surfaces like roads and soil. In contrast, fixed automatic temperature loggers recorded data at a higher frequency, such as every 1 second or every 6 seconds, and were typically used for surfaces like plastic films and cement ground, providing more continuous data capture for specific locations.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of multiscale observation availability affect the methods used for data collection in eco-hydrological research compared to those focusing solely on single-scale observations?
Comparison.Answer: Multiscale observation challenges necessitate the use of hierarchically nested instrumentation, as seen with the HiWATER experiment utilizing diverse tools like eddy covariance towers and remote sensing technologies on various scales. This contrasts with single-scale observations, which might rely on more uniform and less diverse data collection methods. The complexity in multiscale setups aims to capture the heterogeneous nature of eco-hydrological processes, whereas single-scale methods might not address the interactions and variability as comprehensively.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the limited availability of multiscale observations in the field of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited availability of multiscale observations is a challenge due to the complexity and diversity of eco-hydrological processes across different landscapes, which require hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation and a comprehensive network of sensors to adequately capture the interactions and dynamics involved.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences for the accuracy and reliability of temperature measurements when different observation frequencies and instruments are used across varied surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using different observation frequencies and instruments may affect the accuracy and reliability of temperature measurements by introducing variability in data capture. For instance, fixed self-recording thermometers and handheld infrared thermometers have different field of view angles and emissivity settings, which could lead to discrepancies in temperature readings across surfaces like roads and greenhouses. Calibration of instruments at multiple points in time ensures alignment across datasets, potentially enhancing accuracy and reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might arise from implementing multiscale and multidisciplinary instrumentation in observing eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing multiscale and multidisciplinary instrumentation can lead to comprehensive data capture of eco-hydrological processes, which may enhance understanding of surface interactions in heterogeneous areas. This approach, as seen in the HiWATER experiment, addresses the challenge of limited multiscale observations by using a combination of airborne remote sensing and ground-based measurements, which could improve the modeling and prediction of eco-hydrological dynamics.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of synchronizing ground-based surface temperature observations with aerial sensor data in eco-hydrological studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of synchronizing ground-based surface temperature observations with aerial sensor data is to obtain day-to-day temperature variation data for different surface characteristics and to support the validation and scale effect analysis of surface temperature retrieval from airborne TASI sensor data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of using a hierarchically nested observation system in the oasis-desert interface?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives of using a hierarchically nested observation system are to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, investigate oasis-desert interactions, and provide a structured approach for collecting data across various scales and disciplines, thereby enhancing the understanding and modeling of these interactions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific procedures and instruments used to achieve synchronized surface temperature observations in various land cover types during remote sensing flights?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Synchronized surface temperature observations were achieved using handheld infrared thermometers and fixed-point temperature recorders. The handheld infrared thermometers, with a field of view of 1° and an emissivity setting of 0.95, were used to measure temperatures on asphalt roads, ditches, bare soil, watermelon fields, and ridges with an observation frequency of every 5 minutes or continuously during sensor overflights. Fixed-point temperature recorders, with a field of view of approximately 10°, were used for observing plastic film and cement surfaces with observation frequencies ranging from 1s to 6s, depending on the specific land cover and date.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How were the observational instruments calibrated to ensure accurate temperature measurements during the data collection period?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The observational instruments, including handheld infrared thermometers and fixed-point temperature recorders, were calibrated three times during the data collection period on July 6, August 5, and September 20, 2012. This calibration process was essential to ensure accurate and reliable temperature measurements across different surface types and conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies were employed to manage and store the data collected from the surface temperature observations, and how was data quality ensured?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: All observational data were stored in Excel format, which facilitated data management and analysis. Data quality was ensured through careful calibration of the observational instruments on multiple occasions throughout the study period. This process was part of a broader effort to maintain the reliability and accuracy of the collected dataset, supporting further analysis and validation of remote sensing data.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and calibration methods enable the accurate measurement of surface temperature in eco-hydrological research?
Enablement.Answer: The use of hand-held infrared thermometers and fixed point thermometers with specific field of view angles and emissivity settings, along with periodic calibration, enables accurate measurement of surface temperature in eco-hydrological research.

Enablement.Question: How does the implementation of hierarchically nested scales in an experimental setup enable the observation of multiscale eco-hydrological processes?
Enablement.Answer: The implementation of hierarchically nested scales using a sparse network of stations, superstations, and diverse instrumentation, such as eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations, allows for the capture of multiscale eco-hydrological processes across diverse landscapes.

Enablement.Question: What data collection strategies enable the acquisition of multi-angle and hyperspectral data for remote sensing in eco-hydrological research?
Enablement.Answer: The use of airborne remote sensing missions employing LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers enables the acquisition of multi-angle and hyperspectral data crucial for remote sensing in eco-hydrological research.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies of heterogeneous surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies are due to the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is a significant hurdle in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the methodology used in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert areas?
Judgmental.Answer: The methodology employed for collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert areas involves a sophisticated system of hierarchically nested scales, capturing diverse processes through a combination of fixed and mobile instrumentation. This approach seems well-suited for addressing the challenges of data scarcity in heterogeneous surfaces but requires rigorous calibration and quality control to ensure data reliability.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how different data collection methods can be synchronized efficiently to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods can be synchronized by using a hierarchically nested scale approach, which includes arranging instruments like EC towers and automatic meteorological stations in strategic locations, as well as implementing intensive observations at specific intervals, such as during intensive observation periods (IOPs).

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges that arise from poor availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrology research.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges include difficulty in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces and limited progress in understanding these processes due to the lack of comprehensive multiscale data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets from eco-hydrological experiments are quality controlled and made freely accessible.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets are quality controlled through steps such as sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and generation of datasets. They are then made freely available on platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used for synchronizing ground-based surface temperature observations with airborne thermal infrared sensor data in eco-hydrological studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the given field, ground-based surface temperature observations were synchronized with airborne thermal infrared sensor data by using handheld infrared thermometers and fixed-point thermometers. Observations were conducted at specific intervals and synchronized with sensor overflights to validate and analyze the surface temperature data and its scale effects.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the challenges associated with obtaining multiscale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous landscapes and suggest potential strategies to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in obtaining multiscale eco-hydrological data include the poor availability of multiscale observations and capturing processes on heterogeneous surfaces. Strategies used included arranging instruments on hierarchically nested scales, implementing sparse networks, and utilizing a combination of ground measurements and airborne remote sensing missions to cover diverse landscapes and processes.
